columns.text: In this exercise, we will compute the cash break-even quantity, finan.cial break-even quantity, and the  degree of operating leverage.

To get the value for depreciation, we need to divide the initial investment by the number of years.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{D}&=\dfrac{\$34,800}{4}\\
&=\$8,700
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the known values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\$27,300+\$8,700}{\$62-\$28}\\
&=\dfrac{\$36,000}{\$34}\\
&=1058.82
\end{aligned}$$

The accounting break-even point is $1058.82$ units

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\$27,300}{\$62-\$28}\\
&=\dfrac{\$27,300}{\$34}\\
&=802.94
\end{aligned}$$

The cash break-even point is $802.94$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\$27,300+\$34,800}{\$62-\$28}\\
&=\dfrac{\$62,100}{\$34}\\
&=1826.47
\end{aligned}$$

The financial break-even point is $1826.47$

Substitute the values. For this, we will use the OCF as OCF

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=1+\dfrac{\$27,300}{\$34,800}\\
&=1.78
\end{aligned}$$

The degree of operating leverage for the financial break-even is $1.78$
